QUESTION:
Will North Korea deploy military personnel to Ukraine before January 1, 2025?

RESOLUTION CRITERIA:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) report that at least 100 North Korean troops have entered Ukrainian soil before January 1, 2025.

 If no credible reports indicate the simultaneous presence of 100 or more North Korean soldiers in Ukraine, this question will resolve as **No**.

ADDITIONAL CRITERIA:
- Ukrainian soil is defined based on the pre-2014 internationally recognized borders of Ukraine.
- This question pertains only to personnel who have been members of any of the five branches of North Korea's military forces, the Korean People's Army.
- This question will resolve based on the best information available as of January 7, 2025.
- For purposes of this question, troops will count as North Korean military personnel if they are identified as such by credible sources. This is true even in the event of edge cases such as them wearing non-North Korean insignia, being under the command of Russian officers, or being deployed as part of multinational units.  
- Non-combat roles such as logistical support count as well, as long as the North Korean personnel are present on pre-2014 Ukrainian soil.

BACKGROUND:
North Korea and Russia have significantly strenghened their military cooperation since the start of the war in Ukraine. In September 2023, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un [visited Russia](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-66810830), meeting with President Vladimir Putin to discuss potential military and economic collaboration. In early November 2024, Ukraine [fought](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c14le0p4310o) North Korean troops for the first time, while [more recent reports](https://edition.cnn.com/2024/11/10/europe/russia-north-korea-forces-prepared-kursk-ukraine/index.html) claim that 10,000 [North Korean troops](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korean_People%27s_Army) will join Russian soldiers in an attempt to take back the Ukraine-occupied region of Kursk.

[Moreover](https://blog.sentinel-team.org/i/151515209/asia)

> South Korean intelligence reports that an agreement between North Korea and Russia includes an annual supply of 600K to 700K tonnes of rice to North Korea, $200M, space technology, and provisions for Russian involvement in potential conflicts on the Korean Peninsula.

However, until November 12, 2024, there have been no reports of North Korean troops in Ukrainian soil.

- North Korean troops have already been deployed to Russia, specifically to the Kursk Oblast, to support Russian forces in retaking territory from Ukrainian incursions. This deployment includes between 10,000 to 12,000 North Korean soldiers, with some reports indicating that the first units of North Korean personnel were deployed to Kursk Oblast on October 23[3][4][5].

## Operational Strategy
- The Kremlin is currently prioritizing the use of North Korean troops in the Kursk region to help regain control of the territory lost to Ukrainian forces. This strategy allows Russia to re-allocate its own troops to other areas of the front in Ukraine[3][4][5].

## Future Deployment to Ukraine
- It is indicated that North Korean personnel are unlikely to deploy directly into Ukraine until the Kremlin deems that it has properly responded to the Kursk incursion. The primary focus is on maintaining control over the informational effects of using these troops and ensuring they are used effectively within Russian territory before potentially deploying them into Ukraine[3][4].

## Strategic Considerations
- The deployment of North Korean troops is part of a broader strategic cooperation between Russia and North Korea, which includes mutual defense commitments and potential exchanges of military and economic aid. However, the immediate priority for these troops is the Kursk region rather than direct deployment into Ukraine[1][3][4].

Given these points, while it is possible that North Korean troops could be deployed to Ukraine in the future, the current strategy and priorities suggest that such a deployment is unlikely before January 1, 2025, unless there is a significant change in the operational situation or strategic considerations.

### Base Rates and Reference Classes
- The base rate for foreign military interventions involving North Korea is relatively low, and their involvement in European conflicts is unprecedented.
- The reference class of similar military cooperations between Russia and other nations does not provide a clear precedent for immediate deployment into Ukraine.

### Time to Resolution
- The decision to deploy North Korean troops into Ukraine would depend on the resolution of the Kursk incursion and other operational priorities set by the Kremlin.

In summary, while the possibility exists, the current information suggests that a deployment of North Korean troops directly into Ukraine before January 1, 2025, is not imminent based on the prioritization of the Kursk region and the strategic considerations outlined. However, this situation is highly dynamic and subject to change based on various factors.
